frankequote.div: The memorial site for Japanese soldiers killed in action at Blang Bintang, the airport of Banda Aceh. See W. Franke, 1980, p. 250.

names.name: 班達亞齊大亞齊忠魂碑
Banda Aceh Memorial Site for Japanese Soldiers
Banda Aceh Tianyi-she
班達亞齊，大亞齊 天益社

frankequote.div: A small temple located at Jalan Sun Yatsen，and kept up by Chaozhou women from Puning county. The main deity is Guanyin.

The former residence of Majoor Zhang Hongnan 昔張鴻南公館 is located adjacent to the residence of his brother (B 1.23). Zhang Hongnan，Yaoxuan 耀軒，also known as Tjong A Fie，1861-1921，was a Hakka from Meixian, the younger brother of Zhang Yunan (B 1.23), closely working together with the latter. In 1886 the Dutch authorities appointed him Luitenant, and in 1898 Kapitein. After his brother’s death in 1911，he followed him in the position as Ma- joor of Deli. In 1917 he received a honorary Doctor of Laws degree from the University of Hong Kong. In addition, he was engaged in business in China, and received various official Chinese ranks and decorations. In his later years, however, his economic condit­ions deteriorated. The story of the family is told by the daughter from his third wife,Liii Shude, Queeny Chang, Memories of a Nonya, Eastern Universities Press, Singapore 1^81. A Chinese version was published under the title "棉蘭華裔領袖張鴻南 女張福英 女士回憶錄" in 施妙沿叹
w
级Zwo 南洋商報 1 June 1980 and following. See further Suryadinata, 1981,pp. 159-160
Godeley 1981, pp. 15, 186

and the special volume prepared on the occasion of Zhang Hongnan being an official of the Dutch administration for thirty years in 1916

names.name: 先達貧僑收容所
Pematang Siantari Asylum for impoverished Chinese residents

frankequote.div: The main Chinese temple, dating back to the late 19th century. It may have had some connection with the famous Daoist monasteries on Wudangshan, Junxian 均縣，Hubei Province, where Xuantian-Shangdi was said to have lived. On Wudangshan see Claudine Lombard-Salmon, 1969, pp.253
254] Mingsheng cidian, 1981，p.763.

The ancient Chinese Cemetery 昔華人義山 is located opposite the river from the village. The majority of the extant tombstones date from the late Qing and early Republican period. Very few are from the time after the Second World War. The cemetery has been abandoned, since no more Chinese are living at Barus.

frankequote.div: Was at first located on the main road at Martubong, Nanbazhang 南口巴障 (between Titipapan and Labuhan). The old stylish building, still conspicuous in 1987, has been abandoned in the 1980s, and the temple been moved to a private house at Martubong, Lorong 14, No. 5B. It is managed by Fujian people from Zhao'an. Main deities are Chenghuang 城隍 and Jiang-taigong 姜太公.

frankequote.div: "The Nine-Carps-Grotto" is the largest temple at Kisaran，named after the Nine-Carps-Lake in Xianyou county, Xinghua. It is of a rather recent date. Cf. B23.2.

Vihara Pek Kong is located behind Wuzu-miao (B 21.1). In Indonesian it is likewise called Bogong miao 伯公廟. It is dedicated to Han Wengong， i.e •韓愈，768-824，the famous Confucian essayist and poet. — See Arj Ii, 326

names.name: 丹戎勿拉哇文公廟
Tanjung Morawa 印度尼西亚 丹戎勿拉哇, Indonesia Tanjung Morawa Wengong Miao

frankequote.div: Wihara Pekong Lima, the temple of the Five Ancestors, is said to have been moved from Medan to this place, probably in 1972, as the date on the attached photo of the entrance gate indicates. Since the Indonesian name, however, would be equivalent to Old Bogong miao 舊白公廟,it can be supposed that the old temple has been moved to the tomb-site of the Five Ancestors (B 21.1.1) and been combined with a Wuzumiao existing there prior to 1972 (see B 21.1.2). Another, less likely explanation would be, that temple and tomb have been transferred together from the former site to the new location.

frankequote.div: Located at Jalan Jen. Gatot Subroto，but no more extant in the 1980s. It was said to have been set up in late 1909 by Fujian people, but there was no epigraphic evidence for this statement. Main deity was Qingshui-zushi 淸水祖師.

Located at Jalan Jos. Sudarso No. 46, is a pompous new building in modern style, set up in the place of a smaller stylish Guanyin-gong 觀音宮， still extant in the 1970s. The tradition of the latter goes back to the 1880s. It is now managed by Xinghua people. Main deities are Shakyamuni, Guanyin, and Dizang-wang.

frankequote.div: Located at a prominent place in the centre of the small town. The whole compound is fenced, well kept, and probably the most conspicuous Chinese temple in the whole of Aceh. frankequote.div: The former residence of Majoor Zhang Yunan 昔張想南公館 is located at Jalan Perniagaan No. 84. Zhang Yunan, h Rongxuan (Tjong Jong Hian) 榕軒，1859-1911，was a Hakka from Meixian. He set up large rubber estates in the Medan area and became very wealthy and influential. His activities extended to Penang, and he had close connections with the temple Jile-si (see Franke-Chen H1.17). The Imperial Chinese government appointed him first vice-consul (1891-95) and later consul (1895-1900) at Penang. In addition, he received the bottom of the First Rank in 1903 (B 1.23.1 left) and the brevet rank of a Third Rank Director of the Court of Sacrificial Worship in 1907 (B 1.23.2 right) and of a Vice- President of a Ministry (Rank 2A) in 1909 (B 1.23.2 left. Brunnert, 1912, Nos. 966,933, 279/280). About 1884 the Dutch colonial administration appointed him Luitenant of Deli, in the early 20th century Kapitein, and in 1906 (or earlier) Majoor. In 1910, he returned temporarely to China and served the government as Taotai (Rank 4A) (Brunnert, 1912，N.838). His collected writings 海國公餘輯錄 in 6 /wan and Haiguo-gongyu-zalu ^ in 3 juan were first published in 1898. As evident from a document displayed in the former residence, Zhang participated in the Imperial Chinese Naval Affairs study tour to Europe and Japan，headed by Prince Zaixun 載洵，in 1909/1910 (Eccp I, 376 and 386). There are, moreover, photos dedicated to Zhang from Li Yuanhong 黎元鴻，1864* 1928, in the late Qing period first in the navy and then an army organizer under Zhang Zhidong 張之洞 in Hubei, 1916/17 and 1922/23 Chinese president (Bdrc II， 343-346), and from Tang Xiangming 湯蒴銘， who had received naval training in France, and was from 1913-16 military governor of Hunan (Bdrc Iii, 230b and 212a), as well as a postumous record of the merits of Ministry Vice-President Zhang Rongxuan，呢 張榕軒侍郞榮哀錄，a lithographic print made by Huitong 滙通 of Medan，with a preface dated 1917. His wife, Liu Kui-ying 劉葵英，was the daughter of Liu Sheng 劉生，one of the successors of Luo Fangbe 羅芳伯 (see N4). See Franke-Chen p. 627
Luo Xiang-lin, 1961, pp. 99-107
Eccp I, 310
Jimbun-Cat. I p. 372. Suryadinata, 1981, pp. 159-161

names.name: The former residence of Majoor Zhang Yunan in Medan
棉蘭昔張想南公館

frankequote.div: The former Fujian Cemetery 昔福建義山 was located at Petisah 不池沙，Jalan Letja Katamso. It has been confiscated after 1965 by government authorities. The former Cemetery Resthouse has been converted into a store-house (see first two photos). The former temple for Qingshui-zushi 淸水祖師廟 (see third photo) is no longer extant. The two earlier photos were taken by local people. Fortunately the inscribed stone slabs of the cemetery were saved and kept in a private house nearby. Thus, photos could be taken.

The former Fujian Cemetery 昔福建義山 was located at Petisah 不池沙，Jalan Letja Katamso. It has been confiscated after 1965 by government authorities. The former Cemetery Resthouse has been converted into a store-house (see first two photos). The former temple for Qingshui-zushi 淸水祖師廟 (see third photo) is no longer extant. The two earlier photos were taken by local people. Fortunately the inscribed stone slabs of the cemetery were saved and kept in a private house nearby. Thus, photos could be taken.

frankequote.div: The oldest and most important temple, located in the centre of the town. It was built in 1927 and enlarged in 1963-1967, keeping up an earlier tradition (see H5.1.7).'

names.name: 刻一個以「邑」結尾的地名

frankequote.div: A rather large, only Chinese temple and located in the centre of the town. One photo attached shows the front view, the other a poster, set up by the Temple master and four Temple elders in 1972, prohibiting the disposing of trash on the temple premises. It shows that in Indonesia, at least up to the 1970’s, Chinese temples were administered in the traditional way by Luzhu and Toujia. The main deity worshipped is Qingshui-zushi.

frankequote.div: Tianhou-gong (Wihara Ariya Satyani) is located at Jalan Pandu Baru No.2. It is one of the major Chinese temples of Medan, dedicated to Tianhou, and managed by Fujian people.

frankequote.div: located at Labuhan Kota, not far from Shoushan-gong ( 1.3). The date of its foundation could not be established. It has been originally set up by Hakka, but is now managed by Fujian people. Main deities are Shakyamuni, Taisui 太歲，and Zhusheng-niangniang 註生娘遍

frankequote.div: A stylish old temple dedicated to Guanyin (see photo), located at Labuhan 老武漢 Kota, north of Medan. The Chinese settlement at Labuhan ante­dates that of Medan (see B 1.18). The latter, however, became soon the more important place. In 1973 Labuhan was incorporated into the municipality of greater Medan. See U. Wolfram-Seifert, 1981.

frankequote.div: The main Chinese temple in the centre of the town (see attached photo). Among the cult paraphernalia is a beautiful large vase of the Wanli period (1573— 1620) (see photo). The temple was established in 1861 by merchants from Zhangzhou and Quanzhou. (See D1.1.13). The present building dates from the late 19th century and was in 1980 and in 1987 in good condition. The main deity worshipped is Guanyin.
